segment.source: 4718(S) System security access was removed from an account.
segment.target: 4718(S) System security access was removed from an account.

segment.source: (Windows 10)
segment.target: (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes security event 4718(S) System security access was removed from an account.
segment.target: Describes security event 4718(S) System security access was removed from an account.

segment.source: 4718(S): System security access was removed from an account.
segment.target: 4718(S): System security access was removed from an account.

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows Server 2016
segment.target: Windows Server 2016

segment.source: Event Description:
segment.target: Event Description:

segment.source: This event generates every time local logon user right policy is changed and logon right was removed from an account.
segment.target: This event generates every time local logon user right policy is changed and logon right was removed from an account.

segment.source: You will see unique event for every user if logon user rights were removed for multiple accounts.
segment.target: You will see unique event for every user if logon user rights were removed for multiple accounts.

segment.source: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.
segment.target: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.

segment.source: Event XML:
segment.target: Event XML:

segment.source: Required Server Roles: None.
segment.target: Required Server Roles: None.

segment.source: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista.
segment.target: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista.

segment.source: Event Versions: 0.
segment.target: Event Versions: 0.

segment.source: Field Descriptions:
segment.target: Field Descriptions:

segment.source: Subject:
segment.target: Subject:

segment.source: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account that made a change to local logon right user policy.
segment.target: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account that made a change to local logon right user policy.

segment.source: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.
segment.target: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.

segment.source: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.
segment.target: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.

segment.source: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).
segment.target: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).

segment.source: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.
segment.target: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.

segment.source: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.
segment.target: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.

segment.source: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.
segment.target: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.

segment.source: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.
segment.target: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.

segment.source: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.
segment.target: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.

segment.source: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that made a change to local logon right user policy.
segment.target: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that made a change to local logon right user policy.

segment.source: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain or computer name.
segment.target: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain or computer name.

segment.source: Formats vary, and include the following:
segment.target: Formats vary, and include the following:

segment.source: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO
segment.target: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO

segment.source: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local
segment.target: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local

segment.source: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL
segment.target: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL

segment.source: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.
segment.target: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.

segment.source: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.
segment.target: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.

segment.source: Logon ID Type = HexInt64: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”
segment.target: Logon ID Type = HexInt64: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”

segment.source: Account Modified:
segment.target: Account Modified:

segment.source: Account Name Type = SID: the SID of the security principal for which logon right was removed.
segment.target: Account Name Type = SID: the SID of the security principal for which logon right was removed.

segment.source: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.
segment.target: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.

segment.source: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.
segment.target: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.

segment.source: Access Removed:
segment.target: Access Removed:

segment.source: Access Right Type = UnicodeString: the name of removed logon right.
segment.target: Access Right Type = UnicodeString: the name of removed logon right.

segment.source: This event generates only for logon rights, which are as follows:
segment.target: This event generates only for logon rights, which are as follows:

segment.source: Value
segment.target: Value

segment.source: Group Policy Name
segment.target: Group Policy Name

segment.source: SeNetworkLogonRight
segment.target: SeNetworkLogonRight

segment.source: Access this computer from the network
segment.target: Access this computer from the network

segment.target: SeRemoteInteractiveLogonRight

segment.target: Allow logon through Terminal Services

segment.target: SeDenyNetworkLogonRight

segment.target: Deny access to this computer from the network

segment.target: SeDenyBatchLogonRight

segment.target: Deny logon as a batch job

segment.target: SeDenyServiceLogonRight

segment.target: Deny logon as a service

segment.target: SeDenyInteractiveLogonRight

segment.target: Deny logon locally

segment.target: SeDenyRemoteInteractiveLogonRight

segment.source: Deny logon through Terminal Services
segment.target: Deny logon through Terminal Services

segment.target: SeBatchLogonRight

segment.source: Log on as a batch job
segment.target: Log on as a batch job

segment.target: SeServiceLogonRight

segment.target: SeInteractiveLogonRight

segment.source: Security Monitoring Recommendations
segment.target: Security Monitoring Recommendations

segment.source: For 4718(S): System security access was removed from an account.
segment.target: For 4718(S): System security access was removed from an account.

segment.source: Type of monitoring required
segment.target: Type of monitoring required

segment.source: Recommendation
segment.target: Recommendation

segment.source: Actions typically performed by the SYSTEM account: This event and certain other events should be monitored to see if they are triggered by any account other than SYSTEM.
segment.target: Actions typically performed by the SYSTEM account: This event and certain other events should be monitored to see if they are triggered by any account other than SYSTEM.

segment.source: Because this event is typically triggered by the SYSTEM account, we recommend that you report it whenever “SubjectSecurity ID” is not SYSTEM.
segment.target: Because this event is typically triggered by the SYSTEM account, we recommend that you report it whenever “SubjectSecurity ID” is not SYSTEM.

segment.source: High-value accounts: You might have high-value domain or local accounts for which you need to monitor each action.
segment.target: High-value accounts: You might have high-value domain or local accounts for which you need to monitor each action.

segment.source: Examples of high-value accounts are database administrators, built-in local administrator account, domain administrators, service accounts, domain controller accounts and so on.
segment.target: Examples of high-value accounts are database administrators, built-in local administrator account, domain administrators, service accounts, domain controller accounts and so on.

segment.source: Monitor this event with the “SubjectSecurity ID” and “Account ModifiedAccount Name” that correspond to the high-value account or accounts.
segment.target: Monitor this event with the “SubjectSecurity ID” and “Account ModifiedAccount Name” that correspond to the high-value account or accounts.

segment.source: Anomalies or malicious actions: You might have specific requirements for detecting anomalies or monitoring potential malicious actions.
segment.target: Anomalies or malicious actions: You might have specific requirements for detecting anomalies or monitoring potential malicious actions.

segment.source: For example, you might need to monitor for use of an account outside of working hours.
segment.target: For example, you might need to monitor for use of an account outside of working hours.

segment.source: When you monitor for anomalies or malicious actions, use the “SubjectSecurity ID” (with other information) to monitor how or when a particular account is being used.
segment.target: When you monitor for anomalies or malicious actions, use the “SubjectSecurity ID” (with other information) to monitor how or when a particular account is being used.

segment.source: Non-active accounts: You might have non-active, disabled, or guest accounts, or other accounts that should never be used.
segment.target: Non-active accounts: You might have non-active, disabled, or guest accounts, or other accounts that should never be used.

segment.source: Monitor this event with the “SubjectSecurity ID” that corresponds to the accounts that should never be used.
segment.target: Monitor this event with the “SubjectSecurity ID” that corresponds to the accounts that should never be used.

segment.source: Account whitelist: You might have a specific whitelist of accounts that are the only ones allowed to perform actions corresponding to particular events.
segment.target: Account whitelist: You might have a specific whitelist of accounts that are the only ones allowed to perform actions corresponding to particular events.

segment.source: If this event corresponds to a “whitelist-only” action, review the “SubjectSecurity ID” for accounts that are outside the whitelist.
segment.target: If this event corresponds to a “whitelist-only” action, review the “SubjectSecurity ID” for accounts that are outside the whitelist.

segment.source: If you have specific user logon rights policies, for example, a whitelist of accounts that can log on to certain computers, monitor this event to confirm that it was appropriate that the “Access Right” was removed from “Account ModifiedAccount Name.”
segment.target: If you have specific user logon rights policies, for example, a whitelist of accounts that can log on to certain computers, monitor this event to confirm that it was appropriate that the “Access Right” was removed from “Account ModifiedAccount Name.”

segment.source: Accounts of different types: You might want to ensure that certain actions are performed only by certain account types, for example, local or domain account, machine or user account, vendor or employee account, and so on.
segment.target: Accounts of different types: You might want to ensure that certain actions are performed only by certain account types, for example, local or domain account, machine or user account, vendor or employee account, and so on.

segment.source: If this event corresponds to an action you want to monitor for certain account types, review the “SubjectSecurity ID” and “Account ModifiedAccount Name” to see whether the account type is as expected.
segment.target: If this event corresponds to an action you want to monitor for certain account types, review the “SubjectSecurity ID” and “Account ModifiedAccount Name” to see whether the account type is as expected.

segment.source: For example, if critical remote network service accounts have user logon rights which should never be removed (for example, SeNetworkLogonRight), monitor this event for the “Account ModifiedAccount Name” and the appropriate rights.
segment.target: For example, if critical remote network service accounts have user logon rights which should never be removed (for example, SeNetworkLogonRight), monitor this event for the “Account ModifiedAccount Name” and the appropriate rights.

segment.source: As another example, if non-service accounts should never be granted certain logon rights (for example, SeServiceLogonRight), you might monitor this event, because a right can be removed only after it was previously granted.
segment.target: As another example, if non-service accounts should never be granted certain logon rights (for example, SeServiceLogonRight), you might monitor this event, because a right can be removed only after it was previously granted.

segment.source: External accounts: You might be monitoring accounts from another domain, or “external” accounts that are not allowed to perform certain actions (represented by certain specific events).
segment.target: External accounts: You might be monitoring accounts from another domain, or “external” accounts that are not allowed to perform certain actions (represented by certain specific events).

segment.source: Monitor this event for the “SubjectAccount Domain” corresponding to accounts from another domain or “external” accounts.
segment.target: Monitor this event for the “SubjectAccount Domain” corresponding to accounts from another domain or “external” accounts.

segment.source: Restricted-use computers or devices: You might have certain computers, machines, or devices on which certain people (accounts) should perform only limited actions, or no actions at all.
segment.target: Restricted-use computers or devices: You might have certain computers, machines, or devices on which certain people (accounts) should perform only limited actions, or no actions at all.

segment.source: Monitor the target Computer: (or other target device) for actions performed by the “SubjectSecurity ID” that you are concerned about.
segment.target: Monitor the target Computer: (or other target device) for actions performed by the “SubjectSecurity ID” that you are concerned about.

segment.source: Also be sure to check “Account ModifiedAccount Name” to see whether logon rights should be removed from that account.
segment.target: Also be sure to check “Account ModifiedAccount Name” to see whether logon rights should be removed from that account.

segment.source: For high-value servers or other computers, we recommend that you track this event and investigate whether the specific “Access Right” should be removed from “Account ModifiedAccount Name” in each case.
segment.target: For high-value servers or other computers, we recommend that you track this event and investigate whether the specific “Access Right” should be removed from “Account ModifiedAccount Name” in each case.

segment.source: Logon rights that should be restricted: You might have a list of user logon rights that you want to monitor (for example, SeServiceLogonRight).
segment.target: Logon rights that should be restricted: You might have a list of user logon rights that you want to monitor (for example, SeServiceLogonRight).

segment.source: “Deny” rights that should not be removed: Your organization might use “Deny” rights that should not be removed, for example, SeDenyRemoteInteractiveLogonRight.
segment.target: “Deny” rights that should not be removed: Your organization might use “Deny” rights that should not be removed, for example, SeDenyRemoteInteractiveLogonRight.

segment.source: - Monitor this event and compare the “Access Right” to your list of restricted rights.
segment.target: - Monitor this event and compare the “Access Right” to your list of restricted rights.

segment.source: Monitor this event to discover the removal of a right that should never have been granted, so that you can investigate further.
segment.target: Monitor this event to discover the removal of a right that should never have been granted, so that you can investigate further.

segment.source: You can also monitor this event to discover the removal of “Deny” rights.
segment.target: You can also monitor this event to discover the removal of “Deny” rights.

segment.source: When these rights are removed, it could be an approved action, done by mistake, or part of malicious activity.
segment.target: When these rights are removed, it could be an approved action, done by mistake, or part of malicious activity.

segment.source: These rights include:
segment.target: These rights include:

segment.source: SeDenyNetworkLogonRight:
segment.target: SeDenyNetworkLogonRight:

segment.source: SeDenyBatchLogonRight
segment.target: SeDenyBatchLogonRight

segment.source: SeDenyServiceLogonRight
segment.target: SeDenyServiceLogonRight

segment.source: SeDenyInteractiveLogonRight
segment.target: SeDenyInteractiveLogonRight

segment.source: SeDenyRemoteInteractiveLogonRight
segment.target: SeDenyRemoteInteractiveLogonRight

segment.source: Account naming conventions: Your organization might have specific naming conventions for account names.
segment.target: Account naming conventions: Your organization might have specific naming conventions for account names.

segment.source: Monitor “SubjectAccount Name” for names that don’t comply with naming conventions.
segment.target: Monitor “SubjectAccount Name” for names that don’t comply with naming conventions.
